Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a post-doctoral fellowship award that will support an early-career scientist to work on a project entitled: "Evaluating New Zealand as a source of dust to W. Antarctica during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM)".

Atmospheric dust aerosols are a source of iron (Fe) to the Southern Ocean, where micronutrient Fe limits biological production. It is hypothesized that during ice age climates, higher levels of aerosol Fe impacted marine primary production, and thus the global carbon and nitrogen cycles, substantially more than at present. Iron in relatively unweathered dust (such as that from New Zealand) is more soluble and biologically available than that from weathered sediments (such as from Australia). Therefore, a significant New Zealand dust input during glacial times implies a greater role for Fe fertilization of the Southern Ocean's Pacific sector. This project will test the hypothesis that young soils from New Zealand were a significant source of dust to the Southern Ocean and hence West Antarctica during the Last Glacial Maximum. The PI will characterize the New Zealand dust source by collecting samples from well-dated glaciogenic and other aeolian source sediments and analyze them for major and trace element chemistry and strontium, neodymium, lead, and helium isotopic ratios. She will make corollary measurements on samples of glacial-age ice from the Allan Hills (Victoria Land) and the Siple Dome A and Byrd 1968 deep ice cores (West Antarctica) to assess dust provenance in these previously unstudied regions of Antarctica. She also will use a fully coupled global climate model to evaluate the likelihood of dust transport from New Zealand to different regions of Antarctica through time, and the relative climatic importance of New Zealand vs. Australia in terms of iron-fertilization potential of dust deposited in the Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean. The PI will promote broader impacts for science and society by producing and disseminating an outreach video and by working directly in a socioeconomically and racially diverse New York City middle school classroom, where she will teach an earth sciences unit linking concepts from her research to students' own experiences.

Project Summary

Atmospheric dust plays an important role in the global climate system by reducing incoming solar energy and by influencing the cycling of nutrients in the ocean. Dust also acts as a tracer, and can be used to understand how wind systems have changed through time. In fact, dust particles are ideal atmospheric tracers, as particulate chemical and isotopic compositions reflect their source regions. In the same way that a colored dye can be used to track the movement of water, the geochemical fingerprinting of far traveled dust can be used to understand atmospheric transport pathways. As long as we know the composition of the potential dust source regions, we can figure out where the dust came from, and how it traveled.

 

Understanding the sources of dust to the world’s oceans back through time is of particular interest because dust is a source of iron, a required nutrient for organisms that perform nitrogen fixation and photosynthesis, two very important functions. Addition of iron to certain areas of the ocean which naturally have very low iron concentrations can actually stimulate the growth of the bacteria and algae that perform photosynthesis, which on a large scale can impact the global balance of carbon dioxide between the ocean and the atmosphere. This, in turn, can impact global temperatures. Continental landmasses differ in terms of the amount and the form of iron in their bedrock, and therefore the dust produced by these regions can have differing impacts on biology and climate. Dust from relatively arid continents, such as Australia, tends to be relatively chemically altered, and may contain iron that is less readily available to bacteria and algae than fresh dust produced by glaciers through mechanical grinding. This project sought to learn whether glacier-derived sediments from New Zealand might have been an important source of dust to the Southern Ocean in the past. If New Zealand glaciations were a major source of relatively unweathered dust to West Antarctica during the Last Ice Age, it would imply a greater role for dust-derived iron in the Southern Ocean’s Pacific sector (and thus on global temperatures) than currently thought.

 

The first step in this project was to collect samples from regions of New Zealand’s South Island that likely served as dust sources in the past. These included fine-grained sediments produced by mountain glaciers, as well as wind-blown sediments known as loess. We analyzed a wide range of samples in order to learn what the South Island’s geochemical “fingerprint” was. We found that all of the samples looked very similar to each other, but different from Australian sediments. This suggests that dust from New Zealand should be identifiable in downwind locations, such as Antarctic ice cores. The next step was to measure the composition of dust from several ice cores in Antarctica. We focused on the region surrounding the Ross Sea, as few data exist from this area and it is the most likely part of Antarctica to receive dust from New Zealand, given dominant wind patterns. Dust in these ice cores so far looks like it is derived mostly from local (Antarctic) sources, rather than regions in the mid-latitudes. However, samples from a greater range of ages and past climate conditions are needed in order to test comprehensively for dust from New Zealand.
